Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Terahertz System for Medical and Biological Imaging and Nanomaterial Characterization Research at the University of Arkansas

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to support non-destructive, non-hazardous and non-invasive imaging applications in engineering, medical, and biological sciences. The approach is based on pulsed terahertz spectroscopy and imaging that has a spectral range from 0.06 to 3 terahertz with high resolution up to 80 √ùm.
The intellectual merit of this project lies in its contribution to our understanding and utilization of terahertz radiation and imaging techniques in a wide variety of applications. These include investigating breast tumor margins of excised tissue to help reduce cancer recurrence; guiding the fabrication of nano-acoustic imaging materials and devices; studying water content and fungal presence in ecological research, and understanding and monitoring thermal ablation for cancer therapy. The advantage of terahertz light over visible light is that scattering is less allowing imaging deep into an object.
The availability of the terahertz instrument has significant broader impact through providing access to unique education, research and training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Underrepresented students will be engaged in training opportunities through diversity initiatives at the University of Arkansas. Terahertz technology provides non-destructive and rapid characterization of coating materials that will impact automobile, aircraft, food, pharmaceutical, semiconductor, and solar photovoltaic energy industry. The capability of terahertz medical imaging will advance oral healthcare and skin and breast cancer detection and treatment. Terahertz technology provides safe imaging and screening that will advance the identification of hidden explosives and personnel screening at airports and mail screening for bio-threats, which will impact national security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the investigators established a new research facility at the University of Arkansas based on terahertz imaging and spectroscopy technology. The goal of the project was to acquire a pulsed terahertz system that will support innovative research and enhanced training and education for students. The acquired system is capable of imaging and characterization of materials, cancer and other biological tissue, and electronic devices. The investigators succeeded in expanding the research capability at the University of Arkansas and initiated innovative research projects involving breast cancer.

The main outcome of this project was terahertz imaging of excised breast tumor tissues to identify the tumor margins. The goal is to estimate the healthy margins surrounding the excised tumor. Up to this point, the results have been obtained using preserved tissues. The research was conducted in collaboration with a local histopathology clinic for validation. The results showed significant differentiation between cancerous and normal breast tissues in the obtained terahertz images. This outcome is of great significance as it has the potential to reduce breast cancer recurrence. If the margins around the tumor were not clear of cancer, the patient would have to go through a second surgery to remove more tissue. Based on this outcome, the investigators initiated collaboration with the local hospital aiming to prove the same results on freshly excised tumors in the operation room.

In this project, the investigators developed several imaging and characterization algorithms for breast cancer tumors and for industrial applications. Four training workshops were held to provide hands-on experience for diverse undergraduate and graduate students. 

This award has contributed to two masters and two doctoral degrees, twelve undergraduate and graduate students’ training and three Post-Doctoral Fellows' training at the University of Arkansas. The research results were published (or under publication) in three peer reviewed journal papers and 21 refereed conference papers and two undergraduate Honors Theses at the University of Arkansas.
